Suppose we have a system of congruences with different moduli:

\begin{gather} x ≡ b_1 \bmod n_1 \\ x ≡ b_2 \bmod n_2 \\ \vdots \\ x ≡ b_k \bmod n_k \end{gather}

And suppose \((n_i, n_j) = 1\) whenever \(i \ne j\). This means all pairs of \(n\) are coprime. Let \(N = n_1n_2 \ldots n_k\), let \(N_i = \frac{N}{n_i}\) and let \(N_i^{-1}\) be the inverse of \(N_i\) modulo \(n_i\). The solution of the congruences is:

$$ x = N_1N_1^{-1}b_1 + N_2N_2^{-1}b_2 + \ldots + N_kN_k^{-1}b_k $$

Find the least nonnegative solution for this system of congruences:

\begin{gather} x ≡ 2 \bmod 3 \\ x ≡ 1 \bmod 4 \\ x ≡ 3 \bmod 5 \end{gather}

Let \(N = (3)(4)(5) = 60\), \(N_1 = 20\), \(N_2 = 15\) and \(N_3 = 12\). There exists inverses \(N_i^{-1}\):

\begin{gather} 20 N_1^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 3 \implies N_1^{-1} = 2 \\ 15 N_2^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 4 \implies N_2^{-1} = 3 \\ 12 N_3^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \implies N_3^{-1} = 3\end{gather}

So the solution is:

$$\begin{align} x &= N_1N_1^{-1} (2) + N_2N_2^{-1} (1) + N_3N_3^{-1} (3) \\ &= 233 \end{align} $$

This means least nonnegtaive solution mod \(N\) would be \(x = 53\).

Find the least nonnegative solution for this system of congruences:

\begin{gather} x ≡ 1 \bmod 7 \\ x ≡ 4 \bmod 6 \\ x ≡ 3 \bmod 5 \end{gather}

Let \(N = (7)(6)(5) = 210\), \(N_1 = 30\), \(N_2 = 35\) and \(N_3 = 42\). There exists inverses \(N_i^{-1}\):

\begin{gather} 30 N_1^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 7 \implies N_1^{-1} = 4 \\ 35 N_2^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 6 \implies N_2^{-1} = 5 \\ 42 N_3^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \implies N_3^{-1} = 3\end{gather}

So the solution is:

$$\begin{align} x &= N_1N_1^{-1} (1) + N_2N_2^{-1} (4) + N_3N_3^{-1} (3) \\ &= 1198 \end{align} $$

This means least nonnegtaive solution mod \(N\) would be \(x = 148\).

Find the least nonnegative solution for this system of congruences:

\begin{gather} 3x ≡ 2 \bmod 4 \\ 4x ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ 6x ≡ 3 \bmod 9 \end{gather}

Let's focus on \(6x ≡ 3 \bmod 9\) first. This congruence means:

$$ 9 | (6x-3) \implies 9|3(2x-1) $$

Since \(9 \nmid 3\), then \(9 | (2x-1)\), which means:

$$ 2x ≡ 1 \bmod 9 $$

The congruences we need to solve is:

$$\begin{gather} 3x ≡ 2 \bmod 4 \\ 4x ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \\ 2x ≡ 1 \bmod 9 \end{gather}$$

We need them to be in the form of \(x ≡ b \bmod m\), so we can do this:

$$\begin{gather} 3^{-1}3x ≡ 3^{-1}2 \bmod 4 \implies x ≡ 3^{-1}2 \bmod 4 \\ 4^{-1}4x ≡ 4^{-1}1 \bmod 5 \implies x ≡ 4^{-1}1 \bmod 5 \\ 2^{-1}2x ≡ 2^{-1}1 \bmod 9 \implies x ≡ 2^{-1}1 \bmod 9 \end{gather}$$

3-1 modulo 4 is 3, 4-1 modulo 5 is 4 and 2-1 modulo 9 is 5. This means:

$$\begin{gather} x ≡ 6 \bmod 4 \\ x ≡ 4 \bmod 5 \\ x ≡ 5 \bmod 9 \end{gather}$$

Let \(N = (4)(5)(9) = 180\), \(N_1 = 45\), \(N_2 = 36\) and \(N_3 = 20\). There exists inverses \(N_i^{-1}\):

\begin{gather} 45 N_1^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 4 \implies N_1^{-1} = 1 \\ 36 N_2^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 5 \implies N_2^{-1} = 1 \\ 20 N_3^{-1} ≡ 1 \bmod 9 \implies N_3^{-1} = 5\end{gather}

So the solution is:

$$\begin{align} x &= N_1N_1^{-1} (6) + N_2N_2^{-1} (4) + N_3N_3^{-1} (5) \\ &= 914 \end{align} $$

This means least nonnegtaive solution mod \(N\) would be \(x = 14\).
